qas.question: When did Neptune complete it's first barycentric orbit since it's discovery?
Using the heliocentric coordinate system, when did Neptune reach the discovery longitude?
Why didn't Neptune appear to be in it's exact discover position?

answers.text: Earth was in a different location

qas.question: When did Neptune complete it's last barycentric orbit since it's discovery?
Using the heliocentric coordinate system, when did Jupiter reach the discovery longitude?

plausible_answers.text: Earth was in a different location

qas.question: Why did Neptune appear to be in it's exact discover position?

context: On <a0_0><b4_0>11 July 2011<b4_0/><a0_0/>, Neptune completed its first full barycentric orbit since its discovery in 1846, although it did not appear at its exact discovery position in the sky, because <a3_0><b6_0>Earth was in a different location<b6_0/><a3_0/> in its <a1_0>365.26-day<a1_0/> orbit. Because of the motion of the Sun in relation to the barycentre of the Solar System, on 11 July Neptune was also not at its exact discovery position in relation to the Sun; if the more common heliocentric coordinate system is used, the discovery longitude was reached on <a2_0><b5_0>12 July 2011<b5_0/><a2_0/>.
